answer:
JavaScript was initially created to make web pages alive. The programs in this language are called scripts. They can be written right in HTML and run automatically as the page loads. Scripts are provided and executed as plain text. They don't need compilation to run. In case of ES6 code it should be transpiled to ES5 (by means of Babel) and then executed.

JS can be executed not only in the browser but also on the server or actually on any device that has a special program called the JS engine.

JS is a weakly-typed language because it has no compilation stage at which strongly-typed languages validate types.

Primitive types: string number boolean undefined null symbol bigint.
Reference types: Object (incl. Array Function Date Error Map Set).

Primitives are passed by value (value copy); reference types - by reference as a value.

Ways to define type:
1. typeof - not the best way since typeof null and typeof new String('s') and typeof [] are all 'object'
2. instanceof - much better since it looks for the constructor property in the prototype chain; [] instanceof Array is true
3. Object.prototype.toString.call('js') // '[object String]'

1. Function based: function User(name) { this.name = name; } const user = new User('John');
2. Object literal: const user = { name: 'John' };
3. new Object: const user = new Object(); user.name = 'John';
4. Object.create: const user = Object.create(person); // person is user's prototype (user inherits properties of person)

Shallow copy - copy whose properties share the same references (same values that refer to the same memory addresses).
{...obj}; [...arr]; Object.create(); Object.assign(); arr.slice(); Array.from(arr)

Deep copy - copy whose properties are not the same references.
If object is serializable (e.g. not function or HTMLElement) it can deeply copied: JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(obj)).

If object is not serializable (not literal):
function deepCopy(obj) {
  if (!obj) return obj;

  const copyObj = {};
  for (const key in obj) {
    if (typeof obj[key] !== "object" || Array.isArray(obj[key]))
      copyObj[key] = obj[key];
    else copyObj[key] = deepCopy(obj[key]);
  }
  return copyObj;
}

Object.freeze() - fully immutable
Object.seal() - can change values; cannot add or delete or redefine properties
Object.preventExtensions() - can change and delete props; cannot add.

words: use strict mode streak drink mould
answer: In ES5 a new feature called Strict Mode allows to write code in a strict operational environment. It's much less error-prone since all forms of errors(including silent errors) will be thrown.

words: pure your poor function beautiful action beautification
answer:
1. Given the same input always returns the same output.
2. Produces no side-effects.

words: var let bar farm blacked elect
answer:
var has function scope and is initialized with undefined before the code is run due to hoisting.

let has block scope and isn't initialized while getting hoisted. let and const was introduced because function scope is confusing and was one of the main sources of bugs in JS.

words: this these keyword keywords keyboard keyboards
answer:
this refers to the current execution context - the object on which the function was called.

Use-cases:
- method - this refers to object
- regular function - in non-strict mode refers to Window/Global object; in strict mode is undefined
- self-executed function - this refers to Window/Global object
- arrow function - this refers to parent scope
- in class - refers to class object

They allow to redefine this.
call() - invokes a function with a given this value and args provided one by one.
apply() - invokes a function with a given this value and args passed as an array.
bind() - returns a new function that will have this set to the 1st arg passed to bind().

words: hoisting hosting hoist wasting dead dad zone
answer:
Hoisting is the default JS behavior when all the declarations (var const let function class) are moved to the top of their scope (global or local). At the same time var is initialized with undefined. Others (let const class) - not initialized. Calling them before the initialization causes ReferenceError.

Temporal Dead Zone - period of time during which let and const declarations cannot be accessed.

Scope determines the accessibility of vars and funcs at various parts of code. The scope is the current context of execution in which values and expressions are visible or can be referenced. If variable cannot be found in local scope JS engine tries to check for the variable in the outer scope. If no success it tries to find it in the global scope.

Global scope - vars or funcs declared in the global namespace can be accessed from anywhere.
Module scope - exported members of one file can be imported inside another.
Function/local scope - can be accessed from within the function and not outside of it.
Block scope relates only to let and const (var declarations don't have block scope); can be accessed only inside {} block.

words: scope school scola scope chain chaining
answer: JS tries to find variable in local scope and if not then it tries to find var inside upper scope etc until it is found or ReferenceError.

Closure - combination of a function with references to its surrounding state (the lexical environment). In other words closure gives you access to an outer function's scope from an inner function.

In JS closures are created every time a function is created at function creation time.
Currying - partial invocation of a function providing arguments in advance. It creates closure and returns new function. It's possible due to scope chaining.

words: arrow animal function functions fraction fractions
answer:
Arrow functions introduced by ES6. Differences with regular function:
1. this: inside the regular function this keyword refers to the object on which the func is being called whilst inside arrow func this inherits its value from parent scope.
2. constructor - regular func can be used as a constructor for object creation.
3. arguments - inside regular func arguments is an array-like object containing the list of arguments with which func has been invoked; arrow func has no its own arguments keyword.
4. implicit return - undefined is being returned implicitely from regular func if there is no return statement.
5. Regular funcs are hoisted and can be used before declaration (unlike arrow ones).

Map:
- keys can be anything but should be of the same type (same for values)
- iteration order guaranteed (elements in a map retain insertion order)
- has a size property

Object:
- keys must be string literals; values can be anything
- iteration order is not guaranteed
- has prototype
- has no size property

Objects should be used for records where you have a fixed and finite number of properties known at from the beginning. Property access time complexity is O(1)

Maps are for variable number of entries with frequent updates. Property access time complexity is O(1) (O(n) in worst case scenario). But still it is more performant than Object.

Prototype - creational design pattern that lets you copy existing objects without making your code dependent on their classes. In JS it allows to produce objects with methods and properties predefined in the prototype class.

Prototype is useful and memory efficient way of declaring methods for objects of the same type. Alternatively if we'll be declaring methods directly in JS objects a new copy of the method will be created for each instance of an object.

Prototypal inheritance (chaining) is used to build new types of objects based on existing ones. It is similar to inheritance in a class based language.

Object's prototype is available through Object.getPrototypeOf(object) or __proto__ property whereas prototype on constructors function is available through Object.prototype.

Object.prototype functions: toString; toLocaleString; valueOf; hasOwnProperty; isPrototypeOf; propertyIsEnumerable.

hasOwnProperty cannot look into prototype chain proprties.

prototype - property of a Function object; it is prototype of objects constructed by that function.

__proto__ - internal property of an object pointing to its prototype; going upwards the top level __proto__ refers to null.

Event bubbling and capturing are two ways of event propagation in the HTML DOM API when an event occurs in an element inside another element and both elements have registered a handle for that event. The event propagation mode determines in which order the elements receive the event.

Bubbling - event is first captured and handled by the innermost element and then propagated to outer elements.

Capturing - event is first captured by the outermost element and propagated to the inner elements.

addEventListener(type; listener; useCapture)
type - type of event
listener - handler func which is called when event happened
useCapture - indicates whether event is in bubbling phase

stopPropagation() method of the Event interface prevents further propagation of the current event in bubbling and capturing phases. However it doesn't prevent any default behaviors from occurring; for instance click on the link is still processed. To stop this default behavior preventDefault() method should be used. It also does not prevent immediate propagation to other event-handlers. To stop those there is stopImmediatePropagation().

words: async event events loop poop even eventful eventing eventually eventable ivanka antelope micro macro microtask macrotask concurrency
answer:
Event loop - mechanism that allows asynchronously execute non-blocking operations despite the fact JS is single-threaded (which improves the performance of an application).

When an async task is started the EL starts running. Once the task is completed EL again checks for any other tasks that need to be performed. This process continues until all tasks have been completed.

There are 3 "stacks" in JS:
1. synchronous calls stack (one function calls another etc)
2. microtask queue (or job queue or microtask stack) for all async operations with higher priority (process.nextTick Promise Object.observe MutationObserver)
3. macrotask queue (or event queue) for all async operations with lower priority (setTimeout setInterval requestAnimationFrame I/O UI rendering)

Task execution order:
1. all microtasks first
2. one macrotask
3. all (newly added) microtasks again
4. next macrotask
5. repeat

Promise - wrapper/proxy for async operation result which allows via its handlers to resolve it into a sync value. Instead of immediately returning the final value the async method returns promise to supply the value at some point in the future.

Promise is created using the Promise constructor which takes 2 callbacks as parameters: resolve and reject.
Ex: new Promise((resolve; reject) => {resolve(5)}).then(console.log)

Promise states:
1. pending - initial state (promise has neither been fulfilled nor rejected)
2. fulfilled - async operation has accomplished
3. rejected - async operation has failed
4. settled - rejected or fulfilled.

Instance methods: then catch finally

Static methods: resolve reject all allSettled any

window.requestAnimationFrame(callback) - tells the browser that you wish to perform an animation and requests that the browser calls a specified function to update an animation before the next repaint. The method takes a callback as an argument to be invoked before the repaint. Returns request ID - long int value that can be passed to cancelAnimationFrame(id)

requestAnimationFrame vs setTimeout
requestAnimationFrame produces higher quality animation completely eliminating flickering that can happen when using setTimeout or setInterval. This happens because after being put into macrotask queus setTimeout on each EL iteration (after running all the microtasks) checks if it's the right time passed to execute its callback. setTimeout is forced to take at least the amount of time defined by delay.

The time value represents the (minimum) delay after which the message will be pushed into the queue. If there is no other task in the queue and the stack is empty the task is processed right after the delay. However if there are tasks the setTimeout task will have to wait for other tasks to be processed. For this reason 2nd argument indicates a minimum time — not a guaranteed time.

WebSocket - event-driven protocol which means you can actually use it for truly realtime communication.
Unlike HTTP where you have to constantly request updates with WebSocket updates are sent immediately when they are available. WebSocket keeps a single persistent connection open while eliminating latency problems that arise with HTTP request/response-based methods. WebSocket generally does not use XMLHttpRequest so headers are not sent every-time we need to get more information from the server. It reduces the expensive data loads being sent to the server.

1. Cookies
2. Session storage
3. Local storage
4. Cache storage
5. Indexed DB.

words: concurrency multi-threading but parker parkers web when service worker workers water waters walker walkers watercourse porker porkers marker markers
answer:
Workers - scripts that run in a separate thread than the main browser thread. The allow system to run code without blocking. Workers cannot access DOM.

Web workers - not dedicated to some specific kind of work. They just available for main thread's load separation at any moment. They have methods: onmessage; postMessage; onchange; terminate.
// app.js
const ww = new Worker('worker.js');
ww.postMessage('Start');
ww.onmessage = function(e) {console.log(e.data);}
// worker.js
self.onmessage = function(e) {
  console.log(e.data);
  self.postMessage(workerResult);
}
Service worker - script that runs in web browser and manages caching for app. Works with HTTPS not HTTP. SW allow the app to use cached resources first and provide default experience offline before getting more data from the network later. SW actively use promises. SW has to be installed and activated and then it can react on fetch push and sync events.

SW can't access the DOM directly; it can communicate with the pages it controls by responding to messages sent via the postMessage interface and those pages can manipulate the DOM.
Memory model

words: garbage collector collection memory leak leaks
answer:
GC - memory cleanup performed automatically (we cannot force or prevent it).

GC algorythms:
1. Reference count - refs to object are being counted and if the their number is 0 then it's marked as collectible. Mem leak with circular refs thus modern browsers don't use it.
2. Mark-and-sweep - improvement over previous one. Helps to define circular refs. Periodically tries to reach all refs from so-called global root objects. Marks the object as collectible if it cannot be reached from the root one.
3. Generational collection (Mark-and-Sweep optimization) - objects are split into two sets: new ones and old ones. Many objects have a short life span: they appear do their job and die fast so it makes sense to track new objects and clear the memory from them if that's the case. Those that survive for long enough become old and are examined less often.
4. Incremental collection (Mark-and-Sweep optimization) - if there are many objects and we try to walk and mark the whole object set at once it may take some time and introduce visible delays in the execution. So the engine splits the whole set of existing objects into multiple parts. And then clear these parts one after another. There are many small GCs instead of a total one. That requires some extra bookkeeping between them to track changes but we get many tiny delays instead of a big one.
5. Idle-time collection (Mark-and-Sweep optimization) - GC tries to run only while the CPU is idle to reduce the possible effect on the execution.

Memory leaks - Memory leaks = objects that can't be freed up by the GC. Common reasons are closures; timers; detached DOM elements. We can track them through devtools' Memory tab (we can record Heap usage there).

WeakSet - non-iterable collection that contains only objects and no other type. Set contains strong references to the objects whilst WeakSet contains weak references (GCed if no other references to a key object).

WeakMap - non-iterable key/value collection whose keys must be objects without strong references (object's presence as a key in a WeakMap does not prevent the object from being GCed). WeakMap can be useful for mapping keys to values when it's valuable ONLY if the key has not been GCed. Since WeakMap doesn't allow observing the liveness of its keys it is not iterable.

V8 (Chrome) - was originally built for Google Maps introduced in 2004. By that time there was the only JS engine SpiderMonkey which was a simple interpreter-executor and was simple unable to deal with that code.
- parses code
- generates abstract syntax tree
- generates bytecode from this syntax tree
- compiles bytecode into machine code
- uses inline caching

SpiderMonkey (Netscape then Firefox) - first JS engine.

JS Core Webkit (Safari; PlayStation)

Generator - object is returned by a generator function ( function*) and it conforms to both iterable and iterator protocols. Generator's next() method returns obj 
{value: 'a'; done: false}
. done indicates if we passed through this value or not.
JS transpiler used to convert ES6+ to ES5 to be run in any browser. Uses polyfills to provide missing support for various methods.
